Bash(git -c user.name="mcsfeb" -c user.email="mcsfeb@users.noreply.github.com" commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
Fix streaming app detection with alternate package names

Streaming apps have different package names on different devices:
- YouTube TV: com.google.android.youtube.tv \(not .youtube\)
- Max/HBO: com.wbd.stream \(was com.hbo.hbonow, then com.hbo.max.android.tv\)
- YouTube TV service: com.google.android.youtube.tvunplugged

Added altPackageNames field to StreamingApp enum so we check the primary
package AND all known alternates. StreamingLauncher now uses
findInstalledPackage\(\) to detect which variant is actually installed.

Verified on emulator: YouTube, Hulu, Sling, Prime Video, Paramount+,
and Max \(HBO\) are all correctly detected now.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")

Bash(git -c user.name="mcsfeb" -c user.email="mcsfeb@users.noreply.github.com" commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
Fix package detection on API 33+: use PackageInfoFlags API

On Android 13+ \(API 33\), getPackageInfo\(String, int\) is deprecated.
Updated to use getPackageInfo\(String, PackageInfoFlags\) on newer APIs
with fallback for older versions. This should fix apps showing as
"Not Installed" even when they are present on the device.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")

Bash(git -c user.name="mcsfeb" -c user.email="mcsfeb@users.noreply.github.com" commit -m "$\(cat <<''EOF''
Add QUERY_ALL_PACKAGES permission to detect installed streaming apps

On Android 11+ \(API 30+\), apps cannot see other installed packages
by default due to package visibility restrictions. Without this
permission, getPackageInfo\(\) throws NameNotFoundException for every
app, making them all appear as "Not Installed". This was the root
cause of the detection bug.

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
\)")
